skill.name: planning-with-files
skill.description: Transforms workflow to use Manus-style persistent markdown files for planning, progress tracking, and knowledge storage. Use when starting complex tasks, multi-step projects, research tasks, or when the user mentions planning, organizing work, tracking progress, or wants structured output.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code. All content is documentation and workflow guidance for markdown file management. No scripts, network calls, file system access, environment variables, or external commands detected.

content.user_title: Plan complex tasks with persistent markdown files
content.value_statement: AI assistants often lose track of goals during long tasks with many steps. This skill teaches a proven pattern using markdown files as external memory. Create task plans, track progress with checkboxes, and store research notes in files. The assistant stays organized and never loses sight of the original goal.
actual_capabilities: Create task_plan.md files with phases and checkboxes for tracking progress
Maintain notes.md files for storing research findings and intermediate work
Generate deliverable markdown files for final outputs
Apply read-before-decide pattern to keep goals in attention window
Log errors and decisions to build knowledge for future tasks
limitations: Requires the user to work in a persistent filesystem context
Best suited for multi-step tasks spanning several tool calls
Does not execute code or access external APIs directly
Requires manual file creation and updates by the AI

use_cases.title: Track bug fixes
use_cases.description: Break down complex debugging into phases. Track root cause analysis, decisions made, and errors encountered.

use_cases.title: Organize research projects
use_cases.description: Store sources, synthesized findings, and key questions in structured markdown files. Build knowledge as you go.

use_cases.title: Manage feature development
use_cases.description: Plan multi-phase features with clear deliverables. Track decisions and maintain context across long coding sessions.

prompt_templates.title: Start a complex task
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the Planning with Files skill. Create a task_plan.md file with phases, goal, key questions, decisions made, and errors encountered sections. Then create a notes.md file for intermediate findings.

prompt_templates.title: Track progress
prompt_templates.prompt: Using Planning with Files, update task_plan.md by marking the current phase as complete with [x], adding any errors encountered, and updating the status section. Then read both files before continuing.

prompt_templates.title: Store research findings
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply Planning with Files methodology. Write new findings to notes.md with sources and synthesized insights. Update task_plan.md to reflect research progress.

prompt_templates.title: Recover from errors
prompt_templates.prompt: Using Planning with Files, document the error in task_plan.md's Errors Encountered section with the resolution. Then continue from the updated plan.

best_practices: Always create the task_plan.md file before starting any complex task with 3 or more steps
Read task_plan.md before making any major decision to refresh goals in your attention window
Log every error and decision to the plan file instead of hiding failures or losing context
anti_patterns: Using TodoWrite for persistence instead of creating markdown plan files
Starting execution immediately without first creating a structured plan
Stuffing all information in context instead of storing large content in files

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Any AI assistant that can read and write files can use this pattern.

faq.question: How many tool calls can this handle?
faq.answer: The Manus methodology supports approximately 50 tool calls without losing track of original goals through plan file re-reading.

faq.question: Does this integrate with version control?
faq.answer: Yes. The markdown files can be committed to git alongside code, creating a searchable record of decisions and research.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only creates and manages local markdown files in your working directory. No data is sent anywhere.

faq.question: Why not use TodoWrite instead?
faq.answer: TodoWrite is ephemeral and not visible in the attention window. Plan files persist and can be re-read to keep goals front and center.

faq.question: How is this different from regular note-taking?
faq.answer: The key difference is structure: phases with checkboxes, explicit error logging, and the read-before-decide pattern for attention management.
